This
On
Week
List
FICTION

THE DA VINCI CODE, by Dan Brown. (Anchor, $14.95 and $7.99; Broadway special illustrated edition, $22.95.) A murder at the Louvre leads to a trail of clues found in the work of Leonardo and to the discovery of a secret society.
4TH OF JULY, by James Patterson and Maxine Paetro. (Warner Vision, $9.99.) Detective Lindsay Boxer, a member of the Women's Murder Club, looks into a series of killings while she herself is on trial.
BLUE SMOKE, by Nora Roberts. (Jove, $7.99.) An arson investigator whose family suffered a fire when she was a child is menaced by a sociopath.
THE DEVIL WEARS PRADA, by Lauren Weisberger. (Broadway, $13.95; Anchor, $7.99.) A young woman gets a job at a fashion magazine, and a difficult boss.
BLACK WIND, by Clive Cussler and Dirk Cussler. (Berkley, $9.99.) Dirk Pitt and his children confront a villain who has acquired biotoxins from World War II.
ANGELS & DEMONS, by Dan Brown. (Washington Square, $15; Pocket, $9.99 and $7.99.) A scholar tries to save the Vatican from the machinations of an underground society.
THE JURY, by Fern Michaels. (Zebra, $6.99.) While one revenge mission is put off, the sisterhood takes on another: an abusive national security adviser.
MIRACLE, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $7.50.) When a terrible storm hits Northern California, the lives of three people are changed forever.
CORDINA'S ROYAL FAMILY: BENNETT & CAMILLA, by Nora Roberts. (Silhouette, $7.99.) Reprints of two romances involving a prince and princess from the House of Bisset.
SUMMER OF ROSES, by Luanne Rice. (Bantam, $7.50.) The past re-enters the lives of two women and their daughters who fled abusive homes and found refuge in Nova Scotia.
A WEDDING IN DECEMBER, by Anita Shreve. (Back Bay, $14.95.) Seven friends reunite for a wedding and remember the tragedy that drove them apart.
ALWAYS TIME TO DIE, by Elizabeth Lowell. (Avon, $7.99.) Intrigue engulfs a genealogist after she is hired to research the history of a New Mexican family.
LOST LAKE, by Phillip Margolin. (HarperTorch, $9.99.) Two women are caught up in a conspiracy involving a secret unit of assassins.
VELOCITY, by Dean Koontz. (Bantam, $7.99.) A bartender becomes an unwitting accomplice in choosing a serial killer's next victim.
THE KITE RUNNER, by Khaled Hosseini. (Riverhead, $15.95 and $14.) An Afghan-American returns to Kabul to learn how a friend has fared under the Taliban.

This
On
Week
List
NONFICTION
NIGHT, by Elie Wiesel. (Hill & Wang, $9.) A new translation of an account of the horrors of Auschwitz and Buchenwald, first published in English in 1960.
AN INCONVENIENT TRUTH, by Al Gore. (Rodale, $21.95.) The former vice president sounds an alarm about global warming in this companion volume to the movie of the same title.
IN COLD BLOOD, by Truman Capote. (Vintage, $14.) A murder in Kansas in 1959 and its consequences.
THE TIPPING POINT, by Malcolm Gladwell. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $14.95.) A journalist's study of social epidemics, otherwise known as fads.
THE GLASS CASTLE, by Jeannette Walls. (Scribner, $14.) The author recalls a childhood during which she and her siblings were constantly moved.
FLAGS OF OUR FATHERS, by James Bradley with Ron Powers. (Bantam, $14 and $7.99.) The story of the six men who raised the flag at Iwo Jima.
EATS, SHOOTS & LEAVES, by Lynne Truss. (Gotham, $11.) An Englishwoman expounds on the use and misuse of punctuation marks.
THE DEVIL IN THE WHITE CITY, by Erik Larson. (Vintage, $14.95.) The tale of an architect and a killer, linked by the Chicago World's Fair of 1893.
MY FRIEND LEONARD, by James Frey. (Riverhead, $15.) Both author and publisher acknowledge that this book about Frey's helpful mobster friend contains numerous fabrications.
GUNS, GERMS, AND STEEL, by Jared Diamond. (Norton, $16.95.) An argument that Western dominance is due to geographical advantages.
HOLY BLOOD, HOLY GRAIL, by Michael Baigent, Richard Leigh and Henry Lincoln. (Delta, $15; Dell, $7.99.) Remarkable conclusions about Christ's lineage.
GARLIC AND SAPPHIRES, by Ruth Reichl. (Penguin, $15.) The editor of Gourmet relives her days as restaurant critic of The New York Times.
CONFESSIONS OF AN ECONOMIC HIT MAN, by John Perkins. (Plume, $15.) A former employee of an international consulting firm denounces the American global empire and its ''corporatocracy.''
COLLAPSE, by Jared Diamond. (Penguin, $17.) Why some societies succeed and others fail.
THE BOOKSELLER OF KABUL, by Asne Seierstad. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $12.95.) A Norwegian journalist examines the treatment of Afghan women.
110 PEOPLE WHO ARE SCREWING UP AMERICA, by Bernard Goldberg. (Harper Paperbacks, $13.95.) The author of ''Bias'' takes aim at ''Hollywood blowhards,'' ''America bashers,'' rappers and others.

Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous: Hardcover
CESAR'S WAY, by Cesar Millan with Melissa Jo Peltier. (Harmony, $24.95.) The star of the television show ''Dog Whisperer'' offers insight into canine psychology and help solving problems.
THE ALPHABET OF MANLINESS, by Maddox. (Citadel, $15.95.) Ribald humor for men, based on the author's Web site.
LIES AT THE ALTAR, by Robin L. Smith. (Hyperion, $24.95.) A psychologist advises couples on how to turn wedding vows into a successful marriage.
YOUR BEST LIFE NOW, by Joel Osteen. (Warner Faith, $19.99.) A faith-based approach to living with enthusiasm. ()
THE PURPOSE-DRIVEN LIFE, by Rick Warren. (Zondervan, $19.99.) The meaning of life through God. ()

List
Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous: Paperback
RICH DAD, POOR DAD, by Robert T. Kiyosaki with Sharon L. Lechter. (Warner, $16.95.) Teaching one's children how to get rich and stay rich. ()
WHAT TO EXPECT WHEN YOU'RE EXPECTING, by Heidi Murkoff, Arlene Eisenberg and Sandee Hathaway. (Workman, $13.95.) Advice for parents-to-be. ()
SOUL MIND BODY MEDICINE, by Zhi Gang Sha. (New World Library, $15.95.) A guide to healing that starts with the soul. ()
EXPRESS LANE MEALS, by Rachael Ray. (Clarkson Potter, $18.95.) Quick and easy recipes, and what ingredients to shop for, from the Food Network host.
THE SOUTH BEACH DIET, by Arthur Agatston. (St. Martin's, $14.95 and $7.99.) A weight-loss plan.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended June 10, at almost 4,000 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 60,000 other retailers (gift shops, department stores, newsstands, supermarkets), statistically weighted to represent all such outlets nationwide. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger () indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available at The New York Times on the Web: nytimes.com/books
